title: The Super Secret Anthrax ‘BIOWEAPONS’ Accident…That Russia Covered Up! – Science Vibe
cleaned_text:
Anthrax Genome’s “Molecular Fingerprint” BUSTS Soviet ‘BIOWEAPONS’ Accident: In April of 1979, a plume of anthrax spores was accidentally released from a hidden bioweapons facility in the Soviet city of Sverdlovsk. The wind carried the deadly cloud southeast, leaving behind a 50-kilometer lethal trail for humans and animals alike. At least 66 people lost their lives in the incident.

After 37 years of mystery, scientists were finally apple to isolate the pathogen’s DNA from the bodies of two human victims and piece together its entire genome—answering one of many lingering questions about the Soviet Union’s biowarfare program. The results reveal that contrary to initial belief, scientists didn’t tinker with the anthrax strain to make it more resistant to antibiotics or vaccines. It was a perfectly ordinary strain. But that doesn’t mean it wasn’t deadly.

The discovery could also help us in the future if bioterrorists ever get their hands on anthrax.

“It provides us with a molecular fingerprint,” Roland Grunow, an expert on anthrax at the Robert Koch Institute in Berlin, told Science. “If this strain ever surfaces again we will be able to tell that it is the strain that was produced in huge amounts in Sverdlovsk.”

Anthrax is a top choice for use in bioweapons because the bacterium produces spores that can lie dormant in the soil for many decades. Spores are able to be weaponized and delivered by the trillions as an odorless aerosol. Once it reaches the human lung, it will kill 90% of those it infects if it is not treated with antibiotics. If anthrax was released over a city center, tens of thousands could be exposed before officials even recognized what happened. One study estimates that releasing just 1 kilogram of anthrax spores in Washington, D.C. could kill between 4,000 and 50,000 people.

During the Cold War, the Soviet Union had biowarfare programs, as did the United States and the United Kingdom. The Biological Weapons Convention in 1975 was supposed to put an end to that, but a clandestine program in the Soviet Union continued to produced anthrax spores. Questions about the outbreak in Sverdlovsk still remain unanswered. At first, the Soviet Union blamed contaminated meat for the illness—but that was ultimately eliminated as a possibility.

It was that mystery that inspired anthrax scientist Paul Keim of Northern Arizona University to attempt to sequence the B. anthracis genome for samples taken from two victims. The tissue had been fixed in formalin and embedded in paraffin, but researchers were still able to piece together the entire sequence and compare it to other anthrax isolates.

The paper concludes that the Sverdlovsk strain “was one found in the environment which the Russians picked up and used for whatever they were doing there.” Only 13 base pairs differ between the Sverdlovsk strain and its most likely common ancestor strains. This would indicate that scientists in Sverdlovsk slowed evolution.

“I think that the Soviets were meticulous in maintaining master spore stocks and avoiding extensive lab growth,” Keim says.

Today, suspicions remain whether Russia has completely followed through with it’s 1992 agreement to end its bioweapons program. Keim’s study will allow scientists to determine whether any future anthrax outbreak came from a leftover Soviet weapon or some other source.
